newsitem.title: UK: Brent shivers keep North Sea markets cool.
newsitem.headline: Brent shivers keep North Sea markets cool.

text.p: North Sea crudes were unable to throw off a cold caught last week as the benchmark Brent market shivered and other grades showed few signs of improvement, traders said.
Physical Brent traded twice on Monday, at Dec Brent -35 cents for a Nov 15-17 cargo and at Dec Brent -42 cents for a Nov 13-15 loader.
With a sickly Brent/WTI spread keeping the transatlantic arbitrage closed, a potential seller valued the North Sea marker grade at Dec Brent -40 cents, some five cents weaker than on Friday.
"People still believe the next deal will be done at a lower number than the last," said a trader.

Further evidence of weakness at the front end of the market emerged as the Nov/Dec paper spread slipped further into contango, trading at -4 cents after being offered at parity in early dealing. Best bids were coming from -7 cents late in the London session, dealers said.
Dec/Jan also eased to talk at +30/+34 cents.
Brent CFDs painted an equally discouraging picture for sellers, valuing the balance of this week at Dec Brent -40/-35 cents and next week at -36/-30 cents.
Forties managed to cling to a narrow premium to Dated Brent, but sellers of other grades were coy about differentials achieved.

Two Forties, loading Nov 20-22 and Nov 21-23 fetched Dated Brent +5 cents. Norwegian cargoes were said to have traded but details could not be confirmed, although one seller described the market as "stable at around last week's levels."
Nigerian crudes were talking in a two-tiered market with Bonny Light cargoes loading before Nov 25 valued at least five cents below those discussed in late November or early December.
